content.title: Arteriovenous Malformation (Peripheral)
content.summary: Peripheral arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) are high-flow vascular anomalies with abnormal connections between arteries and veins without a normal capillary bed. They are present at birth, grow proportionally with the patient, and may become symptomatic during hormonal changes or trauma.
content.definition: A congenital high-flow vascular malformation characterized by a nidus of abnormal arteriovenous connections without intervening capillaries, resulting in direct arteriovenous shunting

stage_II_expansion.behavior: Growing AVM, may have feeding vessels visible

stage_III_destruction.behavior: Local tissue damage from steal and venous hypertension

stage_IV_decompensation.behavior: Large shunt volume overwhelms cardiac reserve

pathophysiology.embryology: Error in vascular development during embryogenesis

structure.nidus: Central core of abnormal AV connections

hemodynamics.low_resistance: Arteries connect directly to veins; low resistance circuit
hemodynamics.steal_phenomenon: Blood shunted away from normal tissue
hemodynamics.venous_hypertension: High arterial pressure transmitted to veins

clinical_presentation.location: Can occur anywhere; extremities, head/neck, viscera

physical_findings.inspection: Cutaneous staining, visible pulsation, dilated veins

diagnosis.clinical: High-flow features distinguish from low-flow malformations

duplex_ultrasound.findings: High-velocity arterial flow, arterialized venous flow

principles.key_concept: Must treat the nidus, not just feeding vessels
principles.partial_treatment_danger: Proximal ligation causes recruitment and worsening

surgical_resection.indication: Complete excision possible without major morbidity

avoid.proximal_ligation: Causes recruitment of new feeders, makes treatment harder

prognosis.natural_history: Slow progression; may accelerate with triggers
prognosis.palliative: Symptom control achievable in most cases

definition.@value: Congenital high-flow vascular malformation with abnormal arteriovenous connections and a central nidus

learning_objectives: Distinguish AVM from other vascular malformations using ISSVA criteria
Apply Schobinger staging to peripheral AVMs
Explain why proximal ligation is contraindicated
Describe embolization agents and their mechanisms
clinical_pearls: Nidus must be treated - proximal ligation makes things worse
Schobinger Stage IV = high-output cardiac failure
Ethanol is most effective embolic but highest complication risk
Partial treatment may trigger AVM progression
